title: Measuring Misophonia: Assessing the psychometric properties of the MisoQuest and its ability to predict cognitive impacts of triggering sounds
journal: Psychology, University of Western Ontario 12 2Department of Psychology, University of Western Ontario 13 3National Centre for Audi
abstract: Misophonia is a disorder involving an aversion to specific ordinary sounds, such as chewing and breathing. These 'trigger' sounds are easily ignored by typically developed listeners, but elicit negative emotional reactions, physiological stress, and cognitive impairment in people with misophonia. While the severity of this reaction differs across individuals, it is often accompanied by psychological distress. Nevertheless, misophonia is not yet classified as psychological disorder in diagnostic manuals, largely because it is unclear how it should be defined and assessed. Accordingly, the current study aimed to assess the utility of the English language version of the MisoQuest - a recently developed measure of misophonia severity - in a sample of 139 participants, including 44 people with misophonia and 95 controls (96 female, 34 male, 9 transgender/non-binary/non-conforming/agender; 90 White/Caucasian, 10 Black/African Descent, 10 East Asian, 10 South Asian, 3 Middle Eastern/Arab, 3 Latinx/Hispanic, and 13 people from mixed ethnic backgrounds). We first demonstrate that, similar to the original Polish assessment, the English MisoQuest has excellent internal consistency and strong test-retest reliability. Additionally, we provide the first evidence that the MisoQuest specifically taps misophonia symptom severity rather than generalized anxiety or broader sensory sensitivities. Finally, we establish evidence of criterion validity, demonstrating that higher MisoQuest scores predict poorer performance on cognitive tasks in the presence of trigger sounds. Overall, this study indicates that the MisoQuest is a reliable and useful measure for identifying misophonia in English-speaking individuals and that scores on this measure are related to clinically relevant outcomes.

Butler, PhD 36 Department of Psychology 37 1151 Richmond Street N.  38 London, ON N6A 3K7 39 bbutler9@uwo.ca  40

2 Abstract: Misophonia is a disorder involving an aversion to specific ordinary sounds, such as 41 chewing and breathing. These “trigger” sounds are easily ignored by typically developed 42 listeners, but elicit negative emotional reactions, physiological stress, and cognitive impairment 43 in people with misophonia. While the severity of this reaction differs across individuals, it is 44 often accompanied by psychological distress. Nevertheless, misophonia is not yet classified as a 45 psychological disorder in diagnostic manuals, largely because it is unclear how it should be 46 defined and assessed. Accordingly, the current study aimed to assess the utility of the English 47 language version of the MisoQuest - a recently developed measure of misophonia severity - in a 48 sample of 139 participants, including 44 people with misophonia and 95 controls (96 female, 34 49 male, 9 transgender/non-binary/non-conforming/agender; 90 White/Caucasian, 10 Black/African 50 Descent, 10 East Asian, 10 South Asian, 3 Middle Eastern/Arab, 3 Latinx/Hispanic, and 13 51 people from mixed ethnic backgrounds). We first demonstrate that, similar to the original Polish 52 assessment, the English MisoQuest has excellent internal consistency and strong test-retest 53 reliability. Additionally, we provide the first evidence that the MisoQuest specifically taps 54 misophonia symptom severity rather than generalized anxiety or broader sensory sensitivities. 55 Finally, we establish evidence of criterion validity, demonstrating that higher MisoQuest scores 56 predict poorer performance on cognitive tasks in the presence of trigger sounds. Overall, this 57 study indicates that the MisoQuest is a reliable and useful measure for identifying misophonia in 58 English-speaking individuals and that scores on this measure are related to clinically relevant 59 outcomes. 60   61

3 Keywords: Misophonia, MisoQuest, cross-cultural validation, Stroop effect, reading 62 comprehension 63  64 Public Significance Statement: We evaluated the reliability and validity of a measure for 65 misophonia called the MisoQuest. Results indicate that the MisoQuest is a useful measure for 66 identifying misophonia in English-speaking individuals and that scores on this measure are 67 related to clinically relevant outcomes. 68  69   70

4 Misophonia is a psychologically distressing experience involving an extreme aversion to 71 certain ordinary sounds. The clinical presentation of misophonia was first described by Jastreboff 72 & Jastreboff in 2001 and has since garnered increasing awareness among clinicians and 73 researchers. Despite researcher consensus that misophonia is a discrete disorder, there remains a 74 lack of consensus regarding how misophonia should be characterized and assessed (Swedo et al., 75 2022).  76  77 Misophonia Characterization 78 Misophonia is a decreased sound tolerance disorder involving an aversion to specific 79 “trigger” sounds (Siepsiak, Śliwerski, et al., 2020). Any sound can be a trigger for someone with 80 misophonia, but common triggers are human-produced, repetitive sounds like chewing and 81 breathing (Claiborn et al., 2020; Rouw & Erfanian, 2018). When someone with misophonia 82 hears a trigger sound, it elicits a physiological stress response and feelings of intense anger, 83 anxiety, and/or disgust (Edelstein et al., 2013; Kumar et al., 2017; Schröder et al., 2013) 84 Variation in emotional responses to sound is normal, but misophonic reactions can be 85 functionally impairing and clinically significant. Some individuals affected by misophonia 86 describe experiencing pain, suicidal ideation, and/or an inability to enjoy life because of their 87 ongoing symptoms (Alekri & Al Saif, 2019; Hocaoglu, 2018). In addition, behavioral studies 88 demonstrate that people with misophonia experience impaired attention and memory in the 89 presence of trigger sounds when compared to healthy controls (Daniels et al., 2020; Frank et al., 90 2020; Seaborne & Fiorella, 2018; Silva & Sanchez, 2019) These trigger-specific cognitive 91 deficits represent functional impairments that are central to the conceptualization of misophonia. 92

5 Accordingly, validated assessments for misophonia should produce scores that are meaningfully 93 associated with these deficits. 94 Evidence-based clinical assessments and interventions are imperative to the management 95 and treatment of misophonia. However, misophonia is not currently listed in psychiatric 96 diagnostic manuals such as the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual for Mental Disorders (DSM; 97 Gold, 2014). As a result, individuals with misophonia are often misdiagnosed and left without 98 evidence-based treatment options (Brout et al., 2018; Claiborn et al., 2020; Potgieter et al., 2019) 99 This is especially concerning because misophonia has been estimated to affect a staggering 15-100 20% of individuals (Naylor et al., 2021; Wu et al., 2014; Zhou et al., 2017). This point 101 prevalence is alarmingly high given the potential severity of misophonia; however, these 102 estimates were not derived from agreed upon diagnostic criteria. Rather, the prevalence of 103 misophonia has been estimated using self-report measures that do not have rigorously validated 104 clinical cut-offs (Naylor et al., 2021; Wu et al., 2014; Zhou et al., 2017). Thus, while 15-20% of 105 the population may experience misophonia symptoms, clinically significant cases are likely rarer. 106 Regardless, the misophonia literature is sparse (<100 empirical articles published as of 2022; 107 Swedo et al., 2022), suggesting that little is known about a condition that potentially affects 108 many. Validated measures for misophonia are therefore crucial for accurately capturing 109 prevalence, improving clinical practice, and advancing the limited field of research. 110  111 Misophonia Assessment 112         The most widely used self-report measures for misophonia are the Amsterdam 113 Misophonia Scale (A-MISO-S; Schröder et al., 2013) and the Misophonia Questionnaire (MQ; 114 Wu et al., 2014). The popularity of these measures likely reflects the fact that they were the first 115

6 to be developed rather than evidence of their validity (Rosenthal et al., 2021). Both the A-MISO-116 S and MQ were adapted from scales designed to measure Obsessive-Compulsive behaviors, but 117 the conceptualization of misophonia as an obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) has since been 118 criticized. Rather, scientific evidence suggests that while misophonia is highly comorbid with 119 OCD, it is similarly comorbid with other psychological disorders, including mood disorders, 120 anxiety disorders, post-traumatic stress disorder, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder 121 (Claiborn et al., 2020; Jager et al., 2020; Rouw & Erfanian, 2018). In addition, the symptoms 122 captured by OCD measures do not appear to correlate with misophonia-related impairment 123 (Remmert et al., 2022). The psychometric evidence supporting the A-MISO-S and MQ is also 124 incomplete, and comprises data collected exclusively from high school and undergraduate 125 samples (Naylor et al., 2021; Sarıgedik & Gulle, 2021; Wu et al., 2014). Thus, the 126 generalizability of these measures for use with diverse age groups is unclear. 127 To address the absence of a well-validated measure for misophonia, Siepsiak and 128 colleagues (2020a) developed a new self-report measure for misophonia; the MisoQuest is a 129 unidimensional scale comprising 14 Likert-rated items that tap a single underlying construct: 130 misophonia severity. The MisoQuest was shown to have strong internal consistency (Cronbach’s 131 alpha = 0.95) and scores were highly stable over a period of five weeks (interclass correlation 132 coefficient = 0.84; (Siepsiak et al., 2020a). In addition, these psychometric data were acquired 133 from a more diverse sample, providing greater generalizability (Siepsiak et al., 2020a). A 134 receiver operating characteristic analysis of the data provided by Siepsiak and colleagues (2020a) 135 indicated that a cut-off score of 61 resulted in the highest overall accuracy at separating controls 136 (MisoQuest scores between 14-60) from people with misophonia (MisoQuest scores ≥ 61; Enzler 137 et al., 2021). In a follow-up study using that cut-off value, nearly all participants who received a 138

7 MisoQuest score of 61 or greater were diagnosed with misophonia using a structured clinical 139 interview, indicating that the MisoQuest has high specificity (96.3%; Siepsiak et al., 2020b). 140 However, a number of participants who were diagnosed with misophonia using the structured 141 interview scored lower than 61 on the MisoQuest, indicating poorer sensitivity (66.67%; 142 Siepsiak et al., 2020b).  143 In addition to the MisoQuest, a number of other self-report measures have recently been 144 developed to assess misophonia. These include the Selective Sound Sensitivity Syndrome Scale 145 (S-Five; Vitoratou et al., 2021), the Duke Misophonia Questionnaire (DMQ; Rosenthal et al., 146 2021), and the Berlin Misophonia Questionnaire Revised (BMQ-R; Remmert et al., 2022), which 147 also have promising psychometric properties. However, in comparison to these other measures, 148 the MisoQuest has fewer items and may be particularly useful as a rapid screening tool.  149 Overall, the MisoQuest appears to be a reliable and valid measure for identifying 150 misophonia. However, the MisoQuest was written in Polish and validated in Polish-speaking 151 samples before being translated into English by the research team alongside other researchers 152 and interpreters. Several studies have since used the English language MisoQuest to assess 153 misophonia severity (Bagrowska et al., 2022; Enzler et al., 2021; Savard et al., 2022); however, a 154 cross-cultural validation study had yet to be conducted and the properties of the English-155 translated MisoQuest remain unknown. 156   157 The Present Study 158 The goal of this study was to advance the characterization and assessment of misophonia 159 by tackling the following aims: 1) evaluate the psychometric properties (factor structure, internal 160 consistency, and test-retest reliability) of the English language MisoQuest; 2) establish 161

8 preliminary evidence of convergent and discriminant validity of the MisoQuest; 3) investigate 162 group differences in cognitive performance in the presence of different sounds using the 163 MisoQuest cut-off score to group those with and without clinically-significant misophonia; and 164 4) evaluate MisoQuest scores as a dimensional predictor of cognitive performance in the 165 presence of trigger sounds while controlling for general anxiety and sensory hypersensitivity. 166 To address aims three and four, the current study used two cognitive tasks: a Stroop task 167 and a reading comprehension task. Both tasks have been used to identify trigger-specific 168 cognitive deficits in those with misophonia (Daniels et al., 2020; Seaborne & Fiorella, 2018), but 169 are considered to assess different cognitive processes. The Stroop task is used widely throughout 170 psychology research as an indicator of cognitive control and selective attention (Bugg, 2012), 171 whereas reading comprehension is an indicator of sustained attention and memory-related 172 processes (Palladino et al., 2001). By using both tasks, the current study will evaluate the type of 173 cognitive deficits that are associated with MisoQuest scores. 174         In accordance with the psychometric data supporting the original, Polish version of the 175 MisoQuest, we hypothesized that the English language MisoQuest would have a unidimensional 176 factor structure with strong internal consistency and test-retest reliability after five weeks. Next, 177 we hypothesized that scores on the MisoQuest would be strongly correlated with scores on 178 another misophonia measure (the S-Five) but only weakly or moderately correlated with scores 179 on measures for anxiety (the General Anxiety Disorder scale [GAD-7]) and sensory 180 hypersensitivity (the Sensory Hyperactivity Scale [SHS]). We hypothesized that individuals 181 scoring 61 or greater on the  MisoQuest (the previously identified cutoff score for clinically 182 relevant misophonia)would perform worse than control participants on the Stroop and reading 183 comprehension tasks in the presence of trigger sounds. Finally, we hypothesized that MisoQuest 184

9 scores would predict cognitive performance on the Stroop and reading comprehension tasks in 185 the presence of trigger sounds across the spectrum of symptom severity, independent of scores 186 on measures for anxiety and sensory hypersensitivity. 187   188  Methods 189 This study was approved by the University of Western Ontario Research Ethics Board. 190 Study hypotheses and procedures were pre-registered prospectively before data were collected 191 on the Open Science Forum; see https://osf.io/nxhuk. Raw data, supplementary materials, and 192 task code are available at https://osf.io/3pf68. 193  194 Participant Characteristics 195 To calculate the required sample size for this study, an a priori power analysis was run 196 using G*Power (Faul et al., 2007). This analysis was designed to estimate the sample size 197 required to perform a fixed model linear multiple regression with a power of 0.9 and a 198 significance threshold of α = 0.05. The results suggested that a minimum sample size of 90 199 participants (45 per cognitive task) would be required to detect a small effect size. We expected 200 to observe a small effect size (based on the standards of Cohen et al., 1988) because similar 201 effect sizes have been observed in laboratory studies of cognitive functioning in people with 202 misophonia (Frank et al., 2020; Guetta et al., 2022; Simner et al., 2021).  203 Participants were recruited through CloudResearch (New York, NY), the University of 204 Western Ontario SONA psychology research participation pool, and online advertisements 205 circulated to misophonia support groups (including the SoQuiet misophonia research pool). A 206 total of 151 participants were recruited (see Figure 1); however, after excluding participants who 207

10 did not pass the attention checks (described below), a sample of 139 participants was included in 208 the analyses. Forty-four participants met the MisoQuest cut-off for clinically significant 209 misophonia and the remaining 95 participants comprised the control group (see Table 1). The 210 sample was 65% White/Caucasian, 9% East Asian, 9% South Asian, 8% Black/African Descent, 211 5% Latinx/Hispanic, 3% Middle Eastern, and 1% Indigenous Peoples of Canada. Participants 212 also reported their total household income over the past year: 17% of the sample reported an 213 income less than $25,000, 20% reported $25,000-$49,999, 32% reported $50,000-$99,999, 27% 214 reported $100,000-$199,999, and 4% of the sample reported an income greater than $200,000. 215 All participants were 17 years or older, proficient in English, had normal or corrected-to-normal 216 vision, and no known hearing impairments.  217  218 Figure 1 219 Participant Flow Chart  220   221

11 Table 1 222 Participant Characteristics 223     Control (n=95)   Misophonia (n=44)   MisoQuest Score   Range: 14-59 (mean = 39.5)     Range: 61-70 (mean = 65)   Age   Range: 18-73 (mean = 36.5)     Range: 17-72 (mean = 39.5)   Gender   63% female, 33% male, 2% transgender male, 2% non-binary   83% female, 9% male, 2% non-binary, 2% gender non-conforming, 2% agender     224  225 Procedure 226  The study was conducted online using participants’ personal computers. Interested and 227 eligible participants were provided a link to a survey hosted on Qualtrics (Provo, UT). Informed 228 consent was collected, and participants were prompted to complete a self-report assessment 229 battery that included a demographics questionnaire as well as measures for misophonia severity 230 (the MisoQuest and S-Five), generalized anxiety (GAD-7), and sensory hypersensitivity (SHS). 231 Four attention checks were embedded throughout this battery and required participants to select a 232 specific response option (e.g., Please select ‘7’) to indicate that they were reading and 233 responding to each item. Participants who did not select the appropriate response on any of the 234 four attention checks were excluded from all analyses (n = 12). 235

12 Once participants completed the assessment battery, they followed a link to one of two 236 behavioral tasks (either a Stroop or reading comprehension task) written in PsychoPy/PsychoJS 237 (Peirce et al., 2019) and hosted on Pavlovia (Nottingham, UK). To minimize environmental 238 variability, participants were asked to dim their lights, turn up the brightness on their computer 239 screen, minimize distractions, and adjust their computer volume to a level that was loud but not 240 uncomfortable. Participants then completed three blocks of their assigned task, each presented in 241 a different background sound condition: in silence; in the presence of a generally aversive sound 242 (baby crying); or in the presence of a common misophonic trigger sound (a person chewing). The 243 three sound conditions were presented to participants in a random order and were 244 counterbalanced across participants to control for order effects. After completing their assigned 245 behavioral task, participants were asked if at any point during the experiment they had turned the 246 sound off, or reduced the volume such that they could not hear the sounds. Participants who 247 responded “yes” to this question, or did not complete the task in its entirety, or reported 248 encountering technical issues that would preclude the interpretation of their data were excluded 249 from the behavioral analyses (n= 47). Finally, five weeks following the completion of the initial 250 study, participants received a new link hosted on Qualtrics and were asked to complete the 251 MisoQuest a second time. 252  253 Measures 254 Demographics Questionnaire 255       This questionnaire obtained information about a participant’s age, gender, ethnicity, 256 education level, socioeconomic status, and mental health diagnoses. This information was used 257 to ensure similarity across groups and determine the generalizability of study results. In addition, 258

13 participants’ education level was categorized as low (some primary, completed primary, some 259 secondary, secondary degree), medium (some university but no degree, vocational degree ), and 260 high (bachelor's degree, graduate or professional degree) for use as a predictor variable in the 261 regression models. 262  263 MisoQuest  264 The MisoQuest (Siepsiak et al., 2020a) is a 14-item self-report survey that assesses 265 misophonia symptom severity, with questions about emotional reactions to sound and resulting 266 distress and social impairment. The items are rated on a 5-point Likert scale (from 1=I definitely 267 do not agree to 5=I definitely agree) and are summed to produce a total score ranging from 14 268 (no misophonia symptoms) to 70 (severe misophonia symptoms). Scores greater than or equal to 269 61 indicate the presence of clinically significant misophonia. 270  271 Selective Sound Sensitivity Syndrome Scale (S-Five) 272 Participants’ misophonia severity was also quantified using the Selective Sound 273 Sensitivity Syndrome Scale (S-Five; Vitoratou et al., 2021) in order to evaluate convergent 274 validity. The S-Five is a comprehensive, clinically oriented self-report measure that assesses 275 misophonia severity using 25 items distributed across five subscales: internalizing, externalizing, 276 perceived threat, outbursts, and impact. The items are rated on an 11-point scale (from 0=Not at 277 all true to 10=Completely true) and are summed with higher overall scores indicating greater 278 misophonia severity. The S-Five has strong internal consistency, test-retest reliability, and 279 preliminary evidence of convergent and discriminant validity (Vitoratou et al., 2021, 2023).   280  281

14 Generalized Anxiety Disorders Scale (GAD-7) 282 The Generalized Anxiety Disorders Scale (GAD-7; Spitzer et al., 2006) is a 7-item 283 unidimensional scale measuring worry and anxiety symptoms. The items are rated on a 4-point 284 scale (from 0=Not at all to 3=Nearly every day) and are summed to produce a total score ranging 285 from 0 (no or minimal anxiety) to 21 (severe anxiety). The GAD-7 has excellent internal 286 consistency and strong evidence of construct validity (Johnson et al., 2019). 287  288 Sensory Hypersensitivity Scale (SHS) 289 The Sensory Hypersensitivity Scale (SHS; Dixon et al., 2016) is a 25-item self-report 290 survey that assesses sensory over-responsivity. The items are rated on a 5-point Likert scale 291 (from 1=Strongly Disagree to 5=Strongly Agree) and are summed with higher total scores 292 indicating greater sensory over-responsivity. The SHS assesses sensitivity across nine subscales, 293 which correspond to different sensory stimuli, including light, sound, touch, taste, smell, pain, 294 and temperature. The SHS has good internal consistency and evidence of discriminant validity 295 (SHS scores weakly correlate with measures of depression and anxiety [Dixon et al., 2016]). The 296 SHS sound subscale has similarly strong internal consistency.  297  298 Behavioral Tasks & Materials 299 Auditory Stimuli 300       The sound of an individual chewing gum was selected for the misophonic trigger 301 condition because it contained several elements of triggering mouth sounds (i.e., chewing, lip 302 smacking, and wet saliva sounds), which are among the most common triggers for misophonia 303 (Enzler et al., 2021; Vitoratou et al., 2021). Indeed, one study found that 96.5% of individuals 304

15 with self-reported misophonia endorsed mouth sounds as one of their triggers (Claiborn et al., 305 2020). Similarly, the sound of a baby crying sound was selected for the aversive sound condition 306 because it is universally considered to be unpleasant (Green et al., 1995) and is considered 307 similarly aversive by individuals with and without misophonia (Kumar et al., 2017). The gum 308 chewing and baby crying sound files were retrieved from online sources and normalized to have 309 the same root-mean-square amplitude. 310  311  Stroop Task 312 In each trial of the Stroop task, participants were presented with a color word (“red”, 313 “green”, or “blue”) on their computer screen and instructed to use their keyboard arrow keys to 314 indicate the color of the text as quickly and accurately as possible while ignoring the semantic 315 meaning of the word (the mapping of colors to arrow keys was presented at the bottom of the 316 screen as a reminder throughout the experiment). On congruent trials, the color of the text 317 matched the meaning of the word (e.g., the word “red” written in the red text), while on 318 incongruent trials, the color of the text differed from the meaning of the word (e.g., the word 319 “red” written in blue text). Participants completed one block of 30 practice trials, followed by 320 three blocks of 72 experimental trials, each presented in one of the three sound conditions. 321 Within each experimental block , participants were presented with 36 congruent trials and 36 322 incongruent trials (in random order) with a 500 ms interval between trials. 323 The Stroop effect was quantified as the difference between a participant’s mean reaction 324 time on congruent trials and incongruent trials. Only trials where the participant responded 325 correctly were included in this analysis. The magnitude of the Stroop effect for each sound 326 condition was used as an index of cognitive control and selective attention, where a larger Stroop 327

16 effect indicates poorer cognitive control and selective attention. Mean percent accuracy across all 328 trials was also analyzed for each sound condition to supplement the interpretation of Stroop 329 effect results.  330  331 Reading Comprehension Task 332 In the reading comprehension task, participants read three short stories on their computer 333 screen (one per sound condition) and answered recall questions after each story. The three stories 334 were “The Pea Blossom", "Sunshine Stories", and "The Snowman" - short children's fairy tales 335 written by Hans Christian Andersen with similar word counts. The text of each story was 336 presented across multiple screens, and participants progressed from one screen to the next by 337 pressing the spacebar on their keyboard. Before beginning the experiment, participants were 338 informed that they would be directed to answer a series of recall questions when they had 339 completed each story, or after 5 minutes had elapsed (whichever came first). Following each 340 story, participants were given as much time as they needed to answer ten multiple choice 341 questions (each with five response options: one correct and four incorrect). The questions were 342 presented on the computer screen one at a time and participants were instructed to use their 343 keyboard keys to select the response option they thought was correct. 344 Reading comprehension accuracy was quantified as the percentage of multiple-choice 345 questions that the participant answered correctly. Reading comprehension accuracy for each 346 sound condition was used as an indicator of sustained attention and working memory, where 347 decreased accuracy indicated poorer sustained attention, encoding, and/or retrieval. 348  349  350

17 Data Analytic Strategy  351 Psychometric Analyses 352 The 14 items of the Polish MisoQuest load onto a single factor, meaning they assess a 353 single underlying construct: misophonia severity (Siepsiak et al., 2020a). To assess whether the 354 factor structure of the English language MisoQuest is consistent with the Polish MisoQuest, 355 confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) was conducted using a unidimensional model. The goodness-356 of-fit of this model to the data was evaluated using a Comparative Fit Index (CFI), Tucker-Lewis 357 Index (TLI), and Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA). Internal consistency was 358 evaluated using Cronbach’s alpha to further assess the homogeneity of the MisoQuest.   359 To evaluate the convergent and discriminant validity of the MisoQuest, Pearson 360 correlation coefficients were computed between each participant’s MisoQuest score and their 361 scores on the S-Five,GAD-7, and SHS. Finally, test-retest reliability was evaluated by re-362 administering the MisoQuest to participants five weeks following completion of the initial study 363 and computing the interclass correlation coefficient. 364  365 Behavioral Task Analyses 366 For categorical analyses, participants were divided into groups comprising those with and 367 without clinically significant misophonia using the proposed cut-off score for the MisoQuest 368 (Siepsiak et al., 2020a). Participants with scores from 14-60 comprised the control group and 369 participants with scores 61-70 comprised the misophonia group. A two-way ANOVA with group 370 (control, misophonia) as a between-subjects factor and sound type (silence, aversive, trigger) as a 371 within-subjects factor was conducted for each task. The magnitude of the Stroop effect and 372 reading comprehension accuracy were used as dependent variables in the two analyses. The 373

18 standard alpha of 0.05 was used to determine the presence of a significant main effect or 374 interaction, and type III sums of squares were specified to account for differences in sample sizes 375 across groups. Since directional predictions were established a priori, we performed one-tailed t-376 tests to interpret significant effects where applicable. 377 In addition to categorical analyses, the MisoQuest was evaluated as a dimensional 378 measure by determining whether MisoQuest scores predict task performance across the full 379 range of sound sensitivity using multiple linear regression. This analysis investigated the 380 influence of three predictor variables (MisoQuest, GAD-7, and SHS) on each dependent variable 381 (Stroop effect and reading comprehension accuracy). In addition to the reported regression 382 coefficients, Pearson correlations were also computed to evaluate the relation between 383 MisoQuest scores and performance outcomes. Since Pearson correlations are susceptible to 384 outlier influence, bivariate outliers were identified by calculating the Mahalanobis distance for 385 each observation in the correlation, which was compared to the critical value on the chi-squared 386 distribution using an alpha of 0.05. All correlation analyses were conducted before and after the 387 removal of identified outliers and interpreted accordingly. 388  389 Results 390 MisoQuest Psychometric Properties 391          A confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) was conducted to verify the factor structure of the 392 English language MisoQuest. CFA using a unidimensional model yielded the following model fit 393 indices: CFI = 0.920, TLI = 0.906, and RMSEA = 0.117. The CFI and TLI values suggest that 394 the proposed unidimensional model is a good fit for the observed data (Hu & Bentler, 1999). 395 However, an RMSEA value of 0.117 suggests a poor fit, and indicates that the unidimensional 396

19 model may not accurately reproduce the observed pattern of covariance (Hu & Bentler, 1999). 397 Given the disagreement between model fit indices, an exploratory factor analysis (EFA) was 398 conducted using principal component analysis to determine if an alternative model may better fit 399 the data. This EFA provided a single factor accounting for 69.4% of the total variance explained, 400 indicating that a unidimensional model best fit the observed data. The standardized factor 401 loadings ranged from 0.714-0.895 (see Table 2) and the internal consistency of the MisoQuest 402 was high (Cronbach’s alpha = 0.966), indicating that the items are strongly correlated with one 403 another and reliably assess a common underlying construct. 404  405 Table 1 406 MisoQuest Factor Loadings 407  Factor   Indicator  Factor Loading   Misophonia Severity        Item 1: Some sounds bother me so much that I have difficulty controlling my emotions.    0.895   Item 2: Unpleasant sounds make me feel overwhelmed.    0.870   Item 3: I become anxious at the mere thought of an unpleasant sound.    0.786  Item 4: I believe that my reactions to sounds are exaggerated, but I can't get rid of them.    0.868  Item 5: When I hear unpleasant sounds, I start sensing emotions in my body (e.g., I sweat, feel pain, feel pressure, my muscles tense).    0.840

20   Item 6: I start feeling anger the moment I see a thing/animal/person that might make an unpleasant sound at any time.    0.714  Item 7: I put a lot of effort into controlling emotions when I hear an unpleasant sound.    0.780  Item 8: If I can, I avoid meeting with certain people because of the sounds they make.    0.770  Item 9: I find some sounds made by the human body unbearable.    0.777  Item 10: I feel that my mental state worsens if I cannot leave a place where there's an unpleasant sound.    0.864  Item 11: I often think about how to drown out unpleasant sounds.    0.745  Item 12: Some unpleasant sounds make me instantly angry.    0.864  Item 13: I am scared that unpleasant sounds may impact my future.    0.762  Item 14: When meeting with other people, I am sometimes irritated because of unpleasant sounds that are present.    0.834  408  409  410

21 The convergent validity analysis (see Figure 2a) revealed a strong, positive correlation 411 between scores on the MisoQuest and scores on the S-Five (r = 0.813, p < 0.001), which 412 demonstrates a high degree of convergence between measures designed to assess the same 413 construct (misophonia severity). There were also significant positive correlations between 414 MisoQuest scores and scores on the GAD-7 (r = 0.522, p < 0.001; Figure 2b), the SHS (r = 415 0.476, p < 0.001; Figure 2c), and the SHS sound subscale (r = 0.447, p < 0.001), indicating that 416 individuals with more severe misophonia symptoms tend to have more severe anxiety and 417 sensory hypersensitivity. Although these variables are meaningfully associated, the relations 418 between scores on the MisoQuest and measures for distinct constructs (GAD-7, SHS, and SHS 419 sound subscale) are weaker than the relation between scores on the MisoQuest and another 420 measure for misophonia (S-Five), thereby demonstrating discriminant validity. 421  422 Figure 2 423 MisoQuest Convergent & Discriminant Validity Analysis 424 
425 Note. Figure 2a depicts the Pearson correlation between MisoQuest scores and S-Five 426 scores; Figure2b depicts the Pearson correlation between MisoQuest scores and GAD-7 427

22 scores; Figure2c depicts the Pearson correlation between MisoQuest scores and SHS 428 scores. The shaded area represents the standard error, **p < 0.001. 429  430 Finally, the test-retest reliability analysis demonstrated consistent results over a five-431 week interval. The interclass correlation coefficient between MisoQuest scores obtained at the 432 two time points was strong (ICC [68.0] = 0.88, p < 0.001), indicating a high degree of reliability 433 across this time period (Figure 3). 434  435 Figure 3 436 MisoQuest Test-Retest Reliability Analysis 437 
 438 Note. Figure 3 depicts the Pearson correlation between MisoQuest scores at time point 1 439 and MisoQuest scores at time point 2 (five weeks later). The shaded area represents the 440 standard error, **p < 0.001. 441  442  443  444

23 Behavioral Task Results 445          Of the 139 participants that completed the assessment battery, 46 were excluded from the 446 behavioral analyses because they did not complete their assigned task in its entirety, reported 447 experiencing technical difficulties, or reported turning their computer volume way down or off 448 such that they were not listening to the study sounds while completing the task. In total, 47 449 participants were included in the Stroop task analyses (35 controls, 12 people with misophonia) 450 and 46 participants were included in the reading task analyses (37 controls, 9 people with 451 misophonia). Notably, 88.6% of the people with misophonia included in the behavioral analyses 452 reported the sound of someone chewing gum as a trigger, indicating that the stimulus used for 453 the misophonic trigger condition likely produced the desired reaction in most of the misophonic 454 sample.  455  456  Stroop Task 457          A repeated measures ANOVA conducted on Stroop effect magnitudes (the difference in 458 reaction times between incongruent and congruent trials) revealed no significant main effect of 459 group (F[1, 45] = 0.192, p = 0.663, η² = 0.002), no significant main effect of sound type (F[2, 45] 460 = 2.13, p = 0.125, η² = 0.021), and no significant interaction (F[2, 45] = 2.16, p = 0.121, η² = 461 0.021; Figure 4a). A repeated measures ANOVA conducted on overall accuracy values (the 462 percentage of correct responses across all trial types) revealed no significant main effect of group 463 (F[1, 45] = 0.015, p = 0.903, η² = 0.000), no significant main effect of sound type (F[2, 45] = 464 1.37, p = 0.259, η² = 0.001), and no significant interaction (F[2, 45] = 2.29, p = 0.107, η² = 465 0.001). 466

24 To analyze the influence of four predictor variables (MisoQuest scores, GAD-7 scores, 467 SHS scores, and education level [low-medium vs medium-high]) on the outcome of interest 468 (Stroop effect in the presence of trigger sounds), a multiple linear regression was conducted to 469 determine the portion of variance in the outcome variable attributed to the combination of 470 predictors. The overall regression was non-significant (R = 0.203, R2 = 0.0413, adjusted R2 = -471 0.0816, F[5, 40] = 0.336, p = 0.888). Furthermore, the Pearson correlation between MisoQuest 472 scores and Stroop effect in the trigger condition was also non-significant (r = 0.057, p = 0.706; 473 Figure 4b). Two bivariate outliers were identified and subsequently removed from the analysis; 474 however, the resulting correlation remained non-significant (r = -0.186, p = 0.232). 475  476 Figure 4 477 Stroop Effect 478 
 479 Note. Figure 4a depicts the mean Stroop effect score for the control group (light grey) and 480 misophonia group (dark grey) for each sound condition, the error bars represent the 481 standard error of the mean. Figure 4b depicts the Pearson correlation between MisoQuest 482

25 scores and Stroop effect magnitudes for the trigger condition. The shaded area represents 483 the standard error, bivariate outliers are circled. 484  485 Reading Comprehension Task 486          A repeated measures ANOVA conducted on reading accuracy scores revealed no 487 significant main effect of group (F[1, 44] = 0.696, p = 0.409, η² = 0.009), a significant main 488 effect of sound type (F[2, 44] = 5.85, p = 0.004, η² = 0.049), and no significant interaction (F[2, 489 44] = 4.97, p = 0.155, η² = 0.016; Figure 5a). Thus, while there are no apparent group differences 490 in reading accuracy scores between controls and people with misophonia, both groups performed 491 worse in the presence of aversive (t[44] = 2.480, ptukey = 0.044) and trigger sounds (t[44] = 3.035, 492 ptukey = 0.011) compared to silence. To ensure accuracy scores were not confounded by a group 493 difference in time-on-task (i.e., to determine whether people with misophonia were advancing 494 through the screens of text more quickly than control participants in an effort to bring about the 495 end of the trial more quickly), an exploratory analysis of reading time was performed. A repeated 496 measures ANOVA revealed no significant main effect of group (F[1, 44] = 0.000, p = 0.976, η² = 497 0.000), a significant main effect of sound type (F[2, 44] = 5.44, p = 0.006, η² = 0.029), and no 498 significant interaction (F[2, 44] = 2.39, p = 0.098, η² = 0.013). Both groups spent more time 499 reading in silence compared to aversive (t[44] = 2.757, ptukey = 0.023) and trigger sounds (t[44] = 500 2.704, ptukey = 0.026). 501   To analyze the influence of the four predictor variables (MisoQuest scores, GAD-7 502 scores, SHS scores, and education level [low-medium vs. medium-high]) on the outcome of 503 interest (reading comprehension in the presence of trigger sounds) a multiple linear regression 504 was conducted to determine the portion of variance in the outcome variable attributed to the 505

26 combination of predictors. The overall regression was significant (R = 0.511 R2 = 0.261, 506 adjusted R2 = 0.169, F[5, 40] = 2.83, p = 0.028). To assess the contributions of individual 507 predictors, the magnitude and statistical significance of the standardized regression coefficients 508 were examined. MisoQuest scores significantly predicted the outcome of interest (B = -0.368, p 509 = 0.038), while GAD-7 scores (B = -0.049, p = 0.772), SHS scores (B = -0.134, p = 0.366), and 510 education level (B = -0.101-0.525, p = 0.380-0.741) had non-significant regression coefficients. 511 This suggests that the severity of an individual’s misophonia predicts reading comprehension 512 accuracy in the presence of trigger sounds, independent from their GAD-7 score, SHS score, and 513 education level. The Pearson correlation between MisoQuest scores and reading comprehension 514 accuracy scores was significant (r = -0.472, p<0.001; Figure 5b), indicating that greater 515 misophonia severity is associated with poorer reading comprehension in the presence of trigger 516 sounds. 517  518 Figure 5 519 Reading Comprehension Accuracy 520 
 521

27 Note: Figure 5a depicts the mean recall accuracy for the control group (light grey) and 522 misophonia group (dark grey) for each sound condition, the error bars represent the 523 standard error of the mean, *p < 0.05. Figure 4b depicts the Pearson correlation between 524 MisoQuest scores and recall accuracy for the trigger condition. The shaded area represents 525 the standard error, **p < 0.001. 526  527 In contrast, the overall regression was non-significant when reading comprehension in 528 presence of aversive sounds (R = 0.371, R2 = 0.138, adjusted R2 = 0.030, F[5.0, 40.0] = 1.28, p = 529 0.292) and reading comprehension in silence (R = 0.276, R2 = 0.076, adjusted R2 = -0.040, F[5, 530 40] = 0.658, p = 0.657) were used as outcome variables. This indicates that MisoQuest scores are 531 not predictive of reading comprehension accuracy in non-trigger sound conditions. 532  533 Discussion 534 The primary objective of the current study was to advance misophonia assessment by 535 conducting a cross-cultural validation of the MisoQuest–a promising self-report measure for 536 misophonia. The study contributes to a growing body of evidence supporting the reliability and 537 validity of the MisoQuest, and provides novel insight into the substantive associations between 538 misophonia symptom severity and commonly associated cognitive impairments. The MisoQuest 539 was originally developed in Polish and had previously only been evaluated in Polish-speaking 540 samples; thus, the current study bridged a critical gap in misophonia assessment by evaluating 541 the psychometric properties of the English language MisoQuest in an English-speaking sample. 542 In alignment with the findings of Siepsiak & colleagues (2020a), we demonstrated that 543 the MisoQuest has excellent internal consistency and strong stability across a five-week interval. 544

28 This indicates that the MisoQuest is a reliable measure for assessing misophonia symptom 545 severity in English-speaking individuals. In addition to replicating the analyses of Siepsiak & 546 colleagues (2020a), we sought to assess the convergent and discriminant validity of the 547 MisoQuest. We demonstrated that MisoQuest scores are strongly associated with scores on 548 another measure for misophonia and only moderately associated with scores on measures for 549 anxiety and general sensory hypersensitivity. Misophonia severity is known to be associated with 550 the severity of anxiety (Bagrowska et al., 2022; Schadegg et al., 2021) and sensory 551 hypersensitivity symptoms (Wu et al., 2014), so moderate associations between these measures 552 likely reflect the comorbidity between these constructs. Thus, our results align with our 553 hypotheses and suggest that the MisoQuest specifically assesses misophonia - a crucial step 554 towards ascertaining the overall construct validity of the MisoQuest. Overall, the psychometric 555 evidence presented here grants researchers and clinicians improved confidence in their ability to 556 accurately assess misophonia severity in English-speaking individuals, and will strengthen the 557 claims of previous and future research studies using the MisoQuest. However, measurement 558 validation is an ongoing process and researchers should continue to evaluate the factor structure, 559 reliability, and validity of the MisoQuest in diverse samples. 560          The sample size for the current study was estimated a priori to ensure a small effect could 561 be detected in the regression analyses that examined the relationship between cognitive 562 impairments and the full range of MisoQuest scores. However, the resulting samples were 563 ultimately underpowered to detect group differences in cognitive outcomes on the Stroop and 564 reading comprehension tasks due to the small number of individuals who reached the MisoQuest 565 cut-off score (n = 12 and n = 9 respectively, where n = 18 was deemed necessary to effectively 566 power the analyses). A trend was observed whereby individuals with clinically significant 567

29 misophonia showed larger Stroop effects and poorer reading comprehension accuracy in the 568 presence of trigger sounds relative to performance in silence than individuals without 569 misophonia. However, these results largely failed to reach statistical significance and should be 570 interpreted accordingly. The MisoQuest cut-off score used to divide participants with and 571 without clinically significant misophonia yields high diagnostic accuracy (Enzler et al., 2021) but 572 sacrifices sensitivity (Siepsiak et al., 2020b), meaning that some individuals with misophonia 573 were likely not captured using this cut-off. The categorical approach to misophonia assessment 574 may therefore make it challenging for researchers to recruit large enough misophonia samples to 575 power their desired analyses. 576 Our dimensional analyses revealed that in the presence of trigger sounds, individuals with 577 higher MisoQuest scores had poorer reading comprehension accuracy. These results suggest that 578 misophonia symptom severity is associated with the magnitude of trigger-specific deficits. In 579 addition, MisoQuest scores were found to predict reading comprehension accuracy independent 580 from general anxiety, sensory hypersensitivity, and education level. However, contrary to 581 previous studies (Daniels et al., 2020; Silva & Sanchez, 2019), MisoQuest scores did not predict 582 an increased Stroop effect when the trigger sound condition was considered in isolation. This 583 suggests that misophonia-specific factors captured by the MisoQuest, such as aversive emotional 584 reactions to trigger sounds, may be related to deficits in working memory and sustained 585 attention, but not selective attention. Importantly, impairments in sustained attention are 586 clinically relevant; previous research in clinical populations has shown that deficits in sustained 587 attention are better predictors of distress and social impairment than deficits in selective attention 588 (Andrade et al., 2009). Future studies may opt to use neuroimaging techniques in conjunction 589

30 with mediation analyses to establish the specific mechanisms underlying deficits in working 590 memory and sustained attention. 591          Some critics have argued that the MisoQuest captures the presence of misophonia but not 592 the severity of symptoms (Rosenthal et al., 2021). The finding that trigger-specific cognitive 593 deficits scale with MisoQuest scores contradicts that claim and suggests that the MisoQuest may 594 be used as a dimensional measure. By treating misophonia as a dimensional construct, 595 researchers can capture a wider range of variability, more effectively power their analyses, 596 achieve greater flexibility in statistical modeling, and develop a more nuanced interpretation of 597 individual differences. Despite these advantages, categorical approaches remain relevant to 598 certain research questions (e.g., regarding the prevalence and onset of misophonia) as well as 599 clinical decision-making. Researchers and clinicians using the MisoQuest categorically should 600 carefully consider if the proposed cut-off score is appropriate for their intended use of the 601 measure. 602  603 Study Limitations 604          It is important to interpret these findings in the context of their limitations. First, the 605 study was conducted online in an effort to recruit a large sample of participants with severe 606 misophonia. While online experiments are certainly more accessible, they sacrifice some 607 experimental control. First, the current study likely experienced greater attrition rates than if the 608 study had been conducted in a lab. A total of 46 participants who completed the survey portion 609 of the study were not included in the behavioral analyses, either because they did not complete 610 their assigned task, experienced technical difficulties, or reported adjusting their computer 611 volume such that they did not listen to the experimental sounds. This group included a 612

31 disproportionate number of people with misophonia, which may have impacted the significance 613 and effect size of the results presented here. Conceivably, many of the participants who reported 614 turning their computer volume down or off may have done so as a result of the distress they were 615 experiencing; as a result, our sample may be biased toward those who experienced less distress 616 or were able to effectively manage their distress. Next, while the Stroop task is a known indicator 617 of selective attention and cognitive control, the reading comprehension task used in this study 618 has not been validated. Rather, the materials for this task were selected and developed by the 619 study team for use in the current study. The recall questions were expected to discriminate 620 between those with and without a strong understanding of the stories but have not been formally 621 evaluated. Finally, while the MisoQuest showed strong convergent validity with the S-Five, there 622 is currently no consensus ‘gold-standard’ diagnostic tool against which the MisoQuest could be 623 compared against. Future studies may opt to include interview-based assessments (e.g., the Duke 624 Misophonia Interview; Guetta et al., 2022), which might further inform the validity of the 625 MisoQuest. 626  627 Constraints on Generality 628 The sample recruited in the current study comprised a sample of 139 participants, 629 including 44 people with misophonia and 95 controls (96 female, 34 male, 9 transgender/non-630 binary/non-conforming/agender; 90 White/Caucasian, 10 Black/African Descent, 10 East Asian, 631 10 South Asian, 3 Middle Eastern/Arab, 3 Latinx/Hispanic, and 13 people from mixed ethnic 632 backgrounds). Thus, while this sample was age and socioeconomically diverse, it was 633 predominantly composed of white females. It is unclear if there are discernable differences in the 634 presentation of misophonia among genders and ethnicities, meaning that these results may not 635

32 generalize to different populations. Thus, the results presented here represent a step towards 636 validating the English-translated MisoQuest, but do not indicate that the MisoQuest is validated 637 for use with all English-speaking individuals.  638   639 Conclusion 640 People with misophonia struggle with aversive reactions to everyday sounds in a modern 641 world that is filled with noise. This experience can be psychologically distressing, socially 642 isolating, and since misophonia is not yet recognized in diagnostic manuals, difficult to identify 643 and manage. The results of this work will therefore not only serve to improve misophonia 644 assessment but also better understand misophonia as a clinical phenomenon and shape the 645 classification process. 646   647
